Description: Body sherd of a North Ionian black-figured pottery open vessel, probably a bowl; interior glazed (fired red); exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of warrior's right leg (with greave in added red and part of sword or similar remaining) to right; remains of object on floor to right, approximating to a lion's paw.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The icongraphy is difficult, with the object to the right of the warrior's leg and the lump on the floor difficult to accommodate. Without the greave on the leg one may have thought of Herakles attacking the lion, already wearing the skin.
Boardman, JHS, 1958, p. 10, no. 31, says 'it might be anything' (within the North Ionian area).
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 3, pl. 4, no. 4)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.983)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
